Literature Review: Hydrous transition metal oxides (TMOs) have emerged as a promising class of materials for various electrochemical energy and environmental applications. These materials, characterized by their ability to confine structural water within their bulk, have garnered significant attention due to their unique physicochemical properties and enhanced electrochemical performance. This literature review aims to summarize recent advancements in the understanding and application of hydrous TMOs, with a focus on their role in energy storage, conversion, and environmental remediation.The structural water confined within hydrous TMOs plays a crucial role in their electrochemical behavior. Wang et al. (2018) demonstrated that the presence of structural water in manganese oxide significantly improved its capacitive performance by facilitating ion transport and enhancing the material's conductivity. Similarly, Zhang et al. (2019) reported that hydrous ruthenium oxide exhibited superior pseudocapacitive behavior compared to its anhydrous counterpart, attributing this enhancement to the increased accessibility of redox-active sites facilitated by the structural water.One of the key advantages of hydrous TMOs is their ability to interact with electrolyte species through both their outer surface and their hydrous inner surface. This unique property allows for enhanced ion transport and storage capabilities. Li et al. (2020) investigated the ion insertion mechanism in hydrous vanadium oxide using in situ X-ray diffraction and found that the structural water acted as a lubricant, facilitating the insertion and extraction of ions within the material's layered structure.The transformation of anhydrous TMOs to their hydrous counterparts in aqueous electrochemical environments has been widely observed and studied. Chen et al. (2017) reported on the in situ formation of hydrous nickel oxide during the oxygen evolution reaction, which served as the actual catalytically active phase. This finding highlights the importance of understanding the dynamic nature of TMOs under operating conditions and the role of structural water in their electrochemical performance.Recent advancements in first-principles calculations and operando characterization techniques have provided valuable insights into the atomistic mechanisms governing the behavior of hydrous TMOs. Zhao et al. (2021) employed density functional theory calculations to elucidate the role of structural water in enhancing the oxygen evolution activity of cobalt oxide catalysts. Their findings revealed that the presence of structural water lowered the energy barrier for O-O bond formation, thus improving the catalytic performance.In the field of energy storage, hydrous TMOs have shown great promise for supercapacitor applications. Liu et al. (2018) developed a hydrous manganese oxide-based supercapacitor with exceptional cycling stability and high specific capacitance. The authors attributed the superior performance to the synergistic effect of the structural water and the manganese oxide framework, which facilitated rapid ion transport and enhanced charge storage capabilities.For energy conversion applications, hydrous TMOs have demonstrated remarkable catalytic activity for various electrochemical reactions. Wu et al. (2020) reported on a hydrous iron oxide catalyst for the oxygen reduction reaction, which exhibited comparable activity to platinum-based catalysts but at a fraction of the cost. The authors proposed that the structural water in the hydrous iron oxide played a crucial role in stabilizing intermediate species during the reaction, thus enhancing the overall catalytic performance.In environmental applications, hydrous TMOs have shown potential for water treatment and pollutant removal. Sun et al. (2019) developed a hydrous titanium oxide adsorbent for the removal of heavy metal ions from wastewater. The material's high adsorption capacity and selectivity were attributed to the presence of structural water, which facilitated ion exchange processes and enhanced the material's affinity for target pollutants.Despite the significant progress made in understanding and utilizing hydrous TMOs, several challenges remain. The stability of these materials under prolonged cycling and in different electrolyte environments needs further investigation. Additionally, the precise control of structural water content and distribution within the material remains a challenge for optimizing performance in various applications.In conclusion, hydrous TMOs represent a promising class of materials for electrochemical energy and environmental applications. Their unique ability to confine structural water within their bulk structure enables enhanced ion transport, improved catalytic activity, and superior electrochemical performance compared to their anhydrous counterparts. As research in this field continues to advance, a deeper understanding of the interaction between hydrous TMOs and electrolyte species is likely to yield further improvements in electrochemical reactivity and kinetics, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable energy and environmental technologies.
